summary: Robert Keeley cashed in 1.83 million American Express reward points to pay tariff bill . Keeley's scramble is part of a broader reckoning for America’s smaller businesses . Another blow could land on July 9, the deadline President Donald Trump has imposed on other countries to secure trade deals with the US .  Among those feeling the pressure are a tight-knit group of guitar-pedal manufacturers . The niche industry offers a window into the economic toll of tariff whiplash on smaller firms . To avoid layoffs among her 35 workers, she tapped the company’s credit line .  Some large companies have promised to invest in domestic manufacturing . Apple Inc. alone plans to spend more than $500 billion in the US over the next four years . Small manufacturers tend not to have the deep pockets or flexibility needed to rebuild supply chains .  Jon Cusack, 55, runs a pedal manufacturer in Holland, Michigan, that builds delay, reverb and other stomp boxes for his brands . He said he spent $200,000 on inventory before tariffs took effect, draining his savings . “I’ve gotten to the point where my slush funds are all gone, and I still am facing several tariff bills coming up,” he said .  Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell says he expects the impact of tariffs to show up in inflation data in coming months . US factory activity contracted for a fourth month in June as orders and employment shrank at a faster pace . Zoom participant Josh Scott, 43, says American businesses pay the tariff .  Before this year’s tariffs she bought blank printed circuit boards from China for $1.40 each, compared with $20.70 to $31.19 for domestic alternatives . “That is not a viable option and would push our prices up far beyond what the market will bear,” she said .  Members of Zoom Zoom discuss the impact of tariffs on small U.S. manufacturers . They use credit-card points to pay tariff bills totaling $10,987.48 on circuit boards from China and other imported components . “They are just convinced that we can just start building transistors and resistors,” Cusack says .  "I don’t think any of us are willing to go down without a fight," Powell says . Powell: "I think we all view this as, you know, a threat to our survival"

Alphabet Inc. (GOOG) shows potential for another earnings beat . This company has seen a nice streak of beating earnings estimates . The average surprise for the last two quarters was 20.26%. For the last reported quarter, Alphabet came out with earnings of $2.81 per share versus the Zacks Consensus Estimate .  The Zacks Earnings ESP (Expected Surprise Prediction) is a great indicator of a future earnings beat, especially when combined with a solid Zacks Rank #3 (Hold) or better . Stocks with the combination of a positive earnings ESP produce a positive surprise nearly 70% of the time . If you have 10 stocks with this combination, the number of stocks that beat the consensus estimate could be as high as seven .  A positive Earnings ESP reading is not indicative of an earnings miss, but a negative value does reduce the predictive power of this metric . The stock's Zacks Rank #3 (Hold) indicates that another beat is possibly around the corner .  Zacks Investment Research: St. Louis-area companies are best-known in the U.S. market . This article was originally published by Zacks.com .

On June 26, Google Cloud service and Pearson entered a multi-year partnership to accelerate new AI-powered products and services . The strategic collaboration between the two companies will focus on personalizing learning for students . It aims to create rich content to ensure an engaging learning experience for students, especially in the K-12 space .  Pearson’s CEO, Omar Abbosh, expressed optimism about how the use of AI could transform education by replacing conventional teaching methods .
